title: SOR and Community Supervision

communications.subject: Nebraska Public Records Act Request: SOR and Community Supervision
communications.communication:
To Whom It May Concern:

Pursuant to the Nebraska Public Records Act, I hereby request the following records:

The exact number of people who are 

1) on both the sex offender registry and probation; and
2) on both the sex offender registry and parole;

as per the latest available data is requested.

If this cannot be provided, I request records that include:

The list of people on probation
The list of people on parole
The list of people on the sex offender registry

as per the latest available data. 

If this data is held by another agency, I request the name of that agency.

The requested documents will be made available to the general public, and this request is not being made for commercial purposes.

In the event that there are fees, I would be grateful if you would inform me of the total charges in advance of fulfilling my request. I would prefer the request filled electronically, by e-mail attachment if available or CD-ROM if not.

Thank you in advance for your anticipated cooperation in this matter. I look forward to receiving your response to this request within 4 business days, as the statute requires.

Sincerely,

Wendy Sawyer

title: LAKE WASHINGTON SCHOOL DISTRICT (2025) - Digital Copies of Internet Video Call Recordings - January 1, 2020 through August 19, 2025

communications.communication:
LAKE WASHINGTON SCHOOL DISTRICT (2025) - Digital Copies of Internet Video Call Recordings - January 1, 2020 through August 19, 2025

08-19-2025

via email: PublicRecordsRequest@lwsd.org

To: Public Records Officer

Lake Washington School District

PUBLIC RECORDS REQUEST RCW 42.56

Pursuant to the Washington Public Records Act (RCW 42.56), I hereby request disclosure of the following public records:

Digital copies of all video recordings of internet-based video calls, meetings, training sessions, town halls, school board meetings, classroom sessions, and any other recorded internet-based communications created, received, or maintained by the District in its care, custody, or control between January 1, 2020 and August 19, 2025

This includes, but is not limited to, digital recordings generated by or through: 

Zoom
Microsoft Teams
Skype
Google Meet
Google Classroom
Google Duo (now Google Meet mobile)
Slack
GoToMeeting / GoToWebinar
Webex (Cisco)
RingCentral
BlueJeans (Verizon)

Apple technology (e.g., FaceTime, iMessage video calls, Apple Classroom, Apple School Manager, Apple Remote Learning tools)

Other comparable platforms in current or past use, such as Zoom for Education, Blackboard Collaborate, Canvas Conferences, Schoology, Clever, Edmodo, Seesaw, Nearpod, Kahoot video, Flip (formerly Flipgrid), or any other system adopted for remote learning, instructional delivery, parent engagement, training, or administrative communications.

SCOPE OF SEARCH

The District’s search should include, at a minimum:

District-controlled systems and servers – including cloud-based storage, internal file shares, Google Drive, OneDrive, SharePoint, or other platforms used by your agenc.

District-owned devices – all computers, laptops, tablets, or phones issued by LWSD that may contain responsive recordings.

Employee-controlled devices/accounts – if responsive recordings were created, stored, or retained on personal devices/accounts while conducting District business or using District-issued equipment, those devices/accounts must also be searched consistent with Nissen v. Pierce County, 183 Wn.2d 863 (2015).

NISSEN AFFIDAVIT AND ALL DEVICE SEARCH REQUIRED

Pursuant to Nissen v. Pierce County, 183 Wn.2d 863 (2015), and its progeny, this request specifically includes all responsive public records contained on personal devices or personal accounts (including personal cell phones, text/SMS/MMS, personal email accounts, cloud storage, instant messaging apps, and social media accounts) of any agency employee, official, or contractor where public business may have been conducted.

To comply with this requirement, please:

Conduct a comprehensive all-device search, including both agency-issued and personally owned devices/accounts used for public business.

Require each potentially responsive custodian to execute a Nissen affidavit or sworn certification affirming:

That they conducted a diligent search of all personal and agency devices/accounts reasonably likely to contain responsive records;

The methods used to conduct the search (e.g., search terms, accounts checked, device types); and

Whether any responsive records were located, preserved, and produced.

Produce all responsive records located in such searches along with the executed affidavits.

Failure to obtain and provide sworn Nissen affidavits or equivalent certifications from custodians may constitute an incomplete search in violation of RCW 42.56.520 (requirement for a reasonable and adequate search) and may expose the agency to relief under RCW 42.56.550.

FORMAT OF PRODUCTION

Please provide the video recordings in their original, native digital format (e.g., .mp4, .mov, .avi, .mkv, .wmv, .webm, or platform-native format).

Files should be delivered unedited and uncut, preserving all metadata (timestamps, file properties, source identifiers).

Deliver the records by direct electronic means: either (a) direct email attachment where feasible, or (b) a direct, no-password, no-registration-required download link hosted by your agency.

RECORDS INSTALLMENTS - ORDER OF PRODUCTION

If production of responsive records will be completed in multiple installments, please begin by producing records in REVERSE CHRONOLOGICAL FORMAT BY DATE. The most recent public records should be produced first and the oldest records produced last by date.

DIGITAL COMPRESSION AND FILE MINIMIZATION REQUESTED IN ACCORDANCE WITH RCW 42.56

Pursuant to RCW 42.56.080(2), please provide all responsive electronic records in the fewest number of individual files, preserving native formats wherever possible. Where appropriate, please use free digital compression (.zip or equivalent) to consolidate responsive records into the smallest number of installments for efficiency and economy.

This approach reduces agency burden, promotes prompt disclosure, and minimizes potential costs to the requestor, consistent with the Public Records Act’s directive that agencies provide records in the most “reasonably locatable form” and “fullest assistance to requestors.” See RCW 42.56.100 (agency duty to adopt reasonable rules for providing fullest assistance); RCW 42.56.120(2)(b) (fees must reflect actual costs, not used to discourage access).

Washington courts have consistently held that agencies must facilitate access in a practical, non-burdensome manner. See Fisher Broadcasting-Seattle TV LLC v. City of Seattle, 180 Wn.2d 515, 528 (2014) (agencies must provide records in a usable format when reasonably feasible); Mechling v. City of Monroe, 152 Wn. App. 830, 841 (2009) (PRA is to be liberally construed in favor of disclosure). Producing consolidated, digitally compressed files satisfies these obligations by reducing unnecessary fragmentation and excess per-page charges.

Accordingly, I request that each installment be produced as a single compressed .zip file (or as few as technically necessary), containing all responsive records in native format, to ensure both compliance with RCW 42.56 and an economical calculation of any applicable public records fees.

USE OF THIRD PARTY PORTALS NOT MANDATORY

Please note that under Washington’s Public Records Act, use of a third-party “portal” is not mandatory for requestors. Agencies may not condition access to records on the creation of an account, the use of a login, or the acceptance of third-party vendor terms.

Third-party portals (such as GovQA, NextRequest, JustFOIA, or similar systems) often:

Require account creation or login credentials;

Restrict downloads, viewing times, or re-access;

Remove or disable links after a limited period;

Place records behind commercial platforms operated by for-profit corporations.

These restrictions unlawfully burden and condition access to public records. The Public Records Act forbids agencies from imposing access barriers beyond those authorized by statute.

RCW 42.56.080(2): An agency “shall not deny a request for identifiable public records solely on the basis that the request is overbroad.” Agencies must provide the “fullest assistance” and “most timely possible action” to requestors.

RCW 42.56.550(1): Courts are directed to liberally construe the PRA to ensure access and strictly construe exemptions against withholding.

Fisher Broadcasting-Seattle TV LLC v. City of Seattle, 180 Wn.2d 515, 528 (2014): Agencies must produce records in a “reasonably usable format when feasible.”

Mechling v. City of Monroe, 152 Wn. App. 830, 841 (2009): PRA is to be liberally construed in favor of disclosure and cannot be restricted by agency practices.

Because of this, I respectfully decline use of any third-party portal. Please provide all responsive records via:

Direct electronic email attachment to this requestor’s address, or

A direct, open (no password, no registration required) cloud-based download link hosted by your agency.

PROHIBITION ON THIRD PARTY VENDORS

Do not register this requestor with, nor direct this requestor to, any third-party commercial portal, including but not limited to FOIAOnline, GovQA (a Granicus Corporation), NextRequest, FOIAExpress, JustFOIA, FOIADirect, or any similar online service.

Do not transmit any portion of this request, or responsive records, to any for-profit vendor or portal. Doing so would unlawfully condition access to public records and contravene both RCW 42.56.080 and RCW 42.56.550.

PUBLIC RECORDS REQUESTS SUBMITTED VIA EMAIL

This public records request is being submitted via email, consistent with Washington’s Public Records Act.

RCW 42.56.080(2) provides in relevant part:

“Agencies shall honor requests received in person during an agency’s normal office hours, or by mail or email, for identifiable public records unless exempted by provisions of this chapter. No official format is required for making a records request; however, agencies may recommend that requestors submit requests using an agency-provided form or web page.”

Accordingly:

A request submitted by email is a valid, enforceable method of making a PRA request.

Agencies may recommend, but cannot require, the use of an online portal or official form.

Any refusal to honor this request as submitted would directly conflict with RCW 42.56.080 and the agency’s duty under RCW 42.56.100 to provide the “fullest assistance to requestors” and adopt reasonable rules that do not “unreasonably hinder or delay” access.

Washington courts have emphasized that the PRA must be liberally construed in favor of disclosure and access, and that agencies cannot impose unauthorized barriers:

Mechling v. City of Monroe, 152 Wn. App. 830, 841 (2009) (“The PRA is a strongly worded mandate for broad disclosure of public records.”).

Fisher Broadcasting-Seattle TV LLC v. City of Seattle, 180 Wn.2d 515, 528 (2014) (records must be produced in a reasonably usable format when feasible).

Nissen v. Pierce County, 183 Wn.2d 863, 875 (2015) (the PRA is to be interpreted liberally to promote access and accountability).

Therefore, this request is to be honored and fulfilled by your agency via email, as submitted. Should the agency fail to process this request in compliance with statute, relief will be sought pursuant to RCW 42.56.550 in the form of judicial review, penalties, and attorney’s fees.

FEES

In the event that there are fees, please inform us of the total charges in advance of fulfilling the request in strict compliance with all provisions of the Washington State Public Records Act.

EXEMPTION LOGS

Please ensure that all redactions or exemptions claimed by your agency in the production of responsive records are accompanied by a complete and detailed exemption log.

The log must:

* Identify the valid legal reason (statutory citation) for each exemption;
* Specify the location of each redaction within the record produced (via footnote, coded reference, or margin notation);
* State the number of pages or records withheld in their entirety, if any; and
* Demonstrate that only the **minimal exempt portion** of any record has been withheld, as required by law.

The Washington Public Records Act requires agencies to justify each withholding or redaction:

RCW 42.56.210(3): “Agency responses refusing, in whole or in part, inspection of any public record shall include a statement of the specific exemption authorizing the withholding of the record (or part) and a brief explanation of how the exemption applies to the record withheld.”
RCW 42.56.210(1): Exemptions must be narrowly construed.

Washington courts have repeatedly enforced this duty:

Rental Housing Ass’n of Puget Sound v. City of Des Moines, 165 Wn.2d 525, 538 (2009): Agencies must provide specific explanations for each exemption; conclusory or vague justifications are insufficient.
Sanders v. State*, 169 Wn.2d 827, 845 (2010): “The burden of proof is on the agency to establish that refusal to permit public inspection and copying is in accordance with a statute.”
Resident Action Council v. Seattle Housing Auth.* 177 Wn.2d 417, 433 (2013): Agencies must disclose the non-exempt portions*of records and cannot withhold more than necessary.

Therefore, I request that your agency provide an itemized exemption log with each installment of records produced, in compliance with RCW 42.56.210(3) and the above case law, ensuring transparency and accountability in the redaction process.

COMMERCIAL PURPOSE DECLARATION

Commercial Purpose Declaration

This public records request is not being made for any commercial purpose. The Washington State Public Records Act (PRA) prohibits agencies from disclosing “lists of individuals” for commercial purposes.

RCW 42.56.070(8) states:

“This chapter shall not be construed as giving authority to any agency to give, sell, or provide access to lists of individuals requested for commercial purposes….”

Accordingly:

This request does not seek a “list of individuals.”

This request is not made for any commercial purpose.

This declaration satisfies all requirements of RCW 42.56.070(8) regarding prohibitions on lists and commercial purposes.

Warning: The PRA does not authorize agencies to require requestors to complete additional “commercial purpose declarations” when the request does not seek a list of individuals. Such requirements improperly condition access to public records in violation of RCW 42.56.080(2) (requests must be honored by mail or email, no official format required) and RCW 42.56.100 (agencies must provide the fullest assistance to requestors and may not adopt rules that unreasonably hinder or delay access).

Washington courts have consistently rejected agency attempts to impose conditions not found in statute:

Mechling v. City of Monroe, 152 Wn. App. 830, 841 (2009): The PRA is a strongly worded mandate for broad disclosure; agencies cannot erect unauthorized barriers.

SEIU 925 v. University of Washington, 193 Wn.2d 860, 875 (2019): The PRA is to be liberally construed to promote access, and exemptions must be narrowly applied.

Therefore, no additional commercial purpose declaration will be completed for this request. Any attempt to impose such a requirement would be an unlawful restriction of rights under RCW 42.56.

PRESERVATION OF PUBLIC RECORDS *** ANTICIPATE LITIGATION ***

WAC 44-14-03005 RETENTION OF PUBLIC RECORDS

WAC 44-14-03005 (Retention of Public Records) makes clear that public records are subject to retention schedules, and that unlawful destruction can constitute a crime.

RCW 40.16.010 and RCW 40.16.020 criminalize the unlawful mutilation, destruction, or concealment of public records.

RCW 42.56.100 expressly prohibits an agency from destroying any public record after a public records request has been made for that record, even if the record would otherwise be scheduled for lawful destruction.

In addition, agencies have heightened retention obligations when litigation is reasonably anticipated. Records potentially relevant to actual or anticipated litigation must be preserved until both the public records request and the litigation have been fully resolved.

Legal Consequences of Premature Destruction

In Yacobellis v. City of Bellingham, 55 Wn. App. 706, 780 P.2d 272 (1989), the Court of Appeals held that an agency violates the Public Records Act and is subject to attorneys’ fees and statutory penalties when it destroys responsive records after receiving a public records request.

By contrast, it is not a PRA violation if a record was destroyed prior to the agency’s receipt of a request, provided the destruction was lawful under retention schedules. See Bldg. Indus. Ass’n of Wash. v. McCarthy, 152 Wn. App. 720, 218 P.3d 196 (2009); West v. Dep’t of Natural Resources, 163 Wn. App. 238, 258 P.3d 78 (2011).

Washington courts have emphasized that the Public Records Act (RCW 42.56) and the state’s records retention laws (RCW 40.14) are separate but complementary. Agencies must comply with both.

Accordingly:

Your agency must preserve all potentially responsive records immediately upon receipt of this request.

No responsive records may be altered, deleted, or destroyed until this request has been fully resolved and any related litigation has been lifted.

Any unlawful destruction of responsive records may expose the agency and its officials to criminal liability (RCW 40.16), civil penalties, and mandatory attorneys’ fees (RCW 42.56.550(4)).

COMMUNICATION VIA EMAIL

Please send all requests for clarification, status updates, and production of responsive electronic documents via direct email reply.

The requested documents will be made available to the general public.

Thank you in advance for your anticipated cooperation in this matter. We look forward to receiving your response to this request within 5 business days, as the statute requires.

Good Luck.

title: LAKE WASHINGTON SCHOOL DISTRICT – (2025) Request for all communications between district employees and representatives of JUSTFOIA.com a CivicPlus company

communications.subject: Washington Public Records Act Request: LAKE WASHINGTON SCHOOL DISTRICT – (2025) Request for all communications between district employees and representatives of JUSTFOIA.com a CivicPlus company
communications.communication:
08-19-2025

LAKE WASHINGTON SCHOOL DISTRICT – (2025) Request for all communications between district employees and representatives of JUSTFOIA.com a CivicPlus company 

Via email: PublicRecordsRequest@lwsd.org

Dear Public Records Officer:

This is a request under Washington’s Public Records Act, RCW 42.56.

1) Records Requested (Scope)

Please provide copies of all “records” and “writings” (as those terms are broadly defined in RCW 42.56.010) reflecting communications between any employee, agent, contractor, or representative of Lake Washington School District  and any employee, agent, contractor, or representative of:

JustFOIA (also appears as JustFOIA.com), and/or

CivicPlus (the parent company of JustFOIA).

Timeframe: January 1, 2019 through the date you conduct the final search.

Custodians/Locations (non-exhaustive): District leadership; Public Records/Legal; IT/IS; Finance/Procurement; Communications; any program offices that used JustFOIA; and any shared mailboxes (e.g., publicrecordsrequest@lwsd.org
), Teams/Slack/Google Chat spaces, and vendor portals.

1.a Types of communications (include all formats)

Email (including headers, message bodies, inline images, and attachments).

Text/SMS/MMS (including iMessage, Android, carrier SMS).

Instant messaging & collaboration: Microsoft Teams/Skype, Slack, Google Chat, Zoom/Zoom Chat, Webex, RingCentral, WhatsApp, Signal, Telegram, etc.

JustFOIA/CivicPlus portals: messages, comments, internal/external notes, status updates, ticket threads, and support cases.

Helpdesk/ITSM tickets involving JustFOIA/CivicPlus (ServiceNow, Zendesk, Freshservice, Jira, etc.).

Calendars/Invites (meeting requests, agendas, minutes, chat during meetings).

Voicemail logs/transcripts/recordings and call logs (if used for vendor contact).

File shares & cloud drives that contain such communications (SharePoint/OneDrive/Google Drive/Box/Dropbox).

Letters, memos, meeting notes, handouts, and presentations exchanged with JustFOIA/CivicPlus.

1.b Related records about those communications

Contracts/agreements, SOWs, amendments, quotes, order forms, renewals, NDAs, and procurement/sole-source justifications related to JustFOIA/CivicPlus.

Invoices, purchase orders, payment records, and W-9s.

Implementation and configuration communications: onboarding, data migration, retention rules, security settings, user provisioning, SSO, role/permission matrices.

Training materials (agendas, sign-ins, slide decks, recordings) and policies/SOPs referencing JustFOIA.

Security/Privacy: DPAs, BAAs (if any), SOC/ISO reports provided by vendor, questionnaires, risk assessments, incident notices, breach notifications, or vulnerability communications.

Change requests, enhancement requests, bug reports, downtime/outage notices, maintenance windows.

Usage, audit, and access logs showing communications within the JustFOIA system (e.g., message timestamps, sender/recipient identifiers, ticket comments).

Litigation hold or preservation notices relating to these communications.

2) Electronic Production & Formats

To preserve metadata and ease review, please produce as follows:

Emails: PST ( Microsoft Outlook ) or MBOX containers; if unavailable, EML/MSG with full headers.

Chats/Texts/IM: native exports where supported; otherwise, CSV/JSON with fields for sender, recipients, timestamps (UTC), message/thread IDs, and attachments (export attachments in original formats).

Calendars: ICS where possible; or PDF plus any attachments.

Documents/attachments: original/native formats (DOCX, XLSX, PPTX, PDF, etc.).

Logs/Reports: CSV/JSON preferred.

Delivery: Direct electronic transmission via email attachments or open (no login/registration/password) download link hosted by your agency (e.g., SharePoint/OneDrive public link). Please do not use third-party portals that require creating an account or logging in. A single or series of .zip files is fine.

If any records cannot be produced in the above formats, please produce them in their native format with associated metadata intact.

3) Metadata Requested

Where reasonably available, please include customary metadata fields such as: From, To, CC, BCC, Subject, Sent/Received Date-Time (with timezone/UTC), Message-ID, Conversation/Thread-ID, file names, file sizes, hash values (if held), and folder/location paths.

4) Search Details & Preservation

Please identify the systems searched (Exchange/Outlook/Office 365, Teams, mobile devices, MDM archives, JustFOIA/CivicPlus admin, helpdesk, file shares) and the custodians.

Please describe the search methods/terms used.

If any potentially responsive sources were not searched or are no longer available, please explain why and what preservation steps were taken.

5) Withholding, Redaction, and Exemptions

If you withhold or redact anything, identify the specific exemption under RCW 42.56 and provide a brief written explanation of how it applies to each withheld/redacted portion (RCW 42.56.210(3)). Please produce all segregable portions. For any records withheld in full, please provide an exemption/withholding log describing: date, author/recipient (to the extent disclosable), subject or general description, format, page count, and the precise exemption(s) claimed.

6) Installments & Estimates

Please provide:

An initial acknowledgment within five business days (RCW 42.56.520) with a reasonable time estimate for each installment, and

A cost estimate if fees are anticipated (please itemize and explain).

NISSEN AFFIDAVIT AND ALL DEVICE SEARCH REQUIRED

Such requirements improperly condition access to public records in violation of RCW 42.56.080(2) (requests must be honored by mail or email, no official format required) and RCW 42.56.100 (agencies must provide the fullest assistance to requestors and may not adopt rules that unreasonably hinder or delay access).

Washington courts have consistently rejected agency attempts to impose conditions not found in statute:

Mechling v. City of Monroe, 152 Wn. App. 830, 841 (2009): The PRA is a strongly worded mandate for broad disclosure; agencies cannot erect unauthorized barriers.

SEIU 925 v. University of Washington, 193 Wn.2d 860, 875 (2019): The PRA is to be liberally construed to promote access, and exemptions must be narrowly applied.

Therefore, no additional commercial purpose declaration will be completed for this request. Any attempt to impose such a requirement would be an unlawful restriction of rights under RCW 42.56.

PRESERVATION OF PUBLIC RECORDS *** ANTICIPATE LITIGATION ***

WAC 44-14-03005 RETENTION OF PUBLIC RECORDS

WAC 44-14-03005 (Retention of Public Records) makes clear that public records are subject to retention schedules, and that unlawful destruction can constitute a crime.

RCW 40.16.010 and RCW 40.16.020 criminalize the unlawful mutilation, destruction, or concealment of public records.

RCW 42.56.100 expressly prohibits an agency from destroying any public record after a public records request has been made for that record, even if the record would otherwise be scheduled for lawful destruction.

In addition, agencies have heightened retention obligations when litigation is reasonably anticipated. Records potentially relevant to actual or anticipated litigation must be preserved until both the public records request and the litigation have been fully resolved.

Legal Consequences of Premature Destruction

In Yacobellis v. City of Bellingham, 55 Wn. App. 706, 780 P.2d 272 (1989), the Court of Appeals held that an agency violates the Public Records Act and is subject to attorneys’ fees and statutory penalties when it destroys responsive records after receiving a public records request.

By contrast, it is not a PRA violation if a record was destroyed prior to the agency’s receipt of a request, provided the destruction was lawful under retention schedules. See Bldg. Indus. Ass’n of Wash. v. McCarthy, 152 Wn. App. 720, 218 P.3d 196 (2009); West v. Dep’t of Natural Resources, 163 Wn. App. 238, 258 P.3d 78 (2011).

Washington courts have emphasized that the Public Records Act (RCW 42.56) and the state’s records retention laws (RCW 40.14) are separate but complementary. Agencies must comply with both.

Accordingly:

Your agency must preserve all potentially responsive records immediately upon receipt of this request.

No responsive records may be altered, deleted, or destroyed until this request has been fully resolved and any related litigation has been lifted.

Any unlawful destruction of responsive records may expose the agency and its officials to criminal liability (RCW 40.16), civil penalties, and mandatory attorneys’ fees (RCW 42.56.550(4)).

COMMUNICATION VIA EMAIL

Please send all requests for clarification, status updates, and production of responsive electronic documents via direct email reply.

The requested documents will be made available to the general public.

Thank you in advance for your anticipated cooperation in this matter. We look forward to receiving your response to this request within 5 business days, as the statute requires.

Good Luck.

OCR’s letter also indicates OCR received my complaint on May 23, 2025. Please include all records maintained by the U.S. Department of Education, Office for Civil Rights (OCR) relating to this case.

Scope of records requested:

Complaint intake materials (complaint forms, portals, intake notes, logs, case‑opening entries).

Case processing records (jurisdictional analysis, determinations, dismissal/closure documents, CPM citations and checklists, internal memoranda).

All correspondence (emails, letters, attachments, meeting notes) between OCR staff and the Institution, me, or any third parties regarding this case.

Case tracking data (case logs, indices, ticket numbers), and any search result logs.

Any documents concerning retaliation warnings/notices provided to parties in connection with this case.

Custodians / offices likely to hold responsive records (not exhaustive): the assigned investigator(s) for Case No. 05‑25‑4075, Supervisory Attorney Sandra J. Roesti, Jennifer Bergsieker, and the responsible OCR regional and headquarters units.

Keywords for search: “05‑25‑4075”; “Jeffrey Luffman”; the Institution’s name as stated in the OCR letter; “jurisdiction”; “dismissal”; “CPM §102”; “CPM §108(f)”.

Format & delivery: Please provide all records electronically (PDFs or native electronic format with metadata). If feasible, please provide rolling releases as records are processed.

Fees: Please notify me if estimated fees will exceed $25 before you proceed. I also request a public‑interest fee waiver, as disclosure will contribute significantly to the public’s understanding of OCR operations and is not primarily in my commercial interest.

If you withhold any portion of the records, please release all reasonably segregable material and provide a Vaughn index describing each withheld record and the FOIA exemption(s) claimed.

Thank you for your assistance.

communications.subject: California Public Records Act Request: Public Records Request – ALPR Hot Lists
communications.communication:
To Whom It May Concern:

Pursuant to the California Public Records Act, I hereby request the following records:

1.	A description of all “hot lists” or “custom hot lists” currently maintained for use in Automated License Plate Reader (ALPR) systems.
	
2.	Any policies, agreements, or data-sharing documents identifying external data sources used to populate those lists (e.g., DMV data on suspended/revoked licenses, NCIC, CLETS, Amber Alerts, stolen vehicle databases).
	
3.	The criteria under which plates are added or removed from hot lists.

Please provide documents in electronic form.

The requested documents will be made available to the general public, and this request is not being made for commercial purposes.

In the event that there are fees, I would be grateful if you would inform me of the total charges in advance of fulfilling my request. I would prefer the request filled electronically, by e-mail attachment if available or CD-ROM if not.

Thank you in advance for your anticipated cooperation in this matter. I look forward to receiving your response to this request within 10 calendar days, as the statute requires.

Sincerely,

Concerned Resident

Thank you for submitting a request for public records to Riverside County Sheriff's Department. Your request was received in this office on 8/18/2025 and given the reference number C001586-081825 for tracking purposes. 
 Records Requested: " To Whom It May Concern:

Pursuant to the California Public Records Act, I hereby request the following records:

1. A description of all “hot lists” or “custom hot lists” currently maintained for use in Automated License Plate Reader (ALPR) systems.

2. Any policies, agreements, or data-sharing documents identifying external data sources used to populate those lists (e.g., DMV data on suspended/revoked licenses, NCIC, CLETS, Amber Alerts, stolen vehicle databases).

3. The criteria under which plates are added or removed from hot lists.

Please provide documents in electronic form.

The requested documents will be made available to the general public, and this request is not being made for commercial purposes.

In the event that there are fees, I would be grateful if you would inform me of the total charges in advance of fulfilling my request. I would prefer the request filled electronically, by e-mail attachment if available or CD-ROM if not.

Thank you in advance for your anticipated cooperation in this matter. I look forward to receiving your response to this request within 10 calendar days, as the statute requires.

Sincerely,

Concerned Resident

Upload documents directly: https://accounts.muckrock.com/accounts/login/?next=https%3A%2F%2Fwww.muckrock.com%2Faccounts%2Flogin%2F%3Fnext%3D%252Faccounts%252Fagency_login%252Friverside-county-sheriff-806%252Fpublic-records-request-alpr-hot-lists-191542%252F%253Femail%253Driversidesheriff%252540govqa.us&url_auth_token=AAAwWp029-xdo1eMop4h-6A4ap8%3A1uoC2D%3AkmSaiGxndOF1UAGDC-zL4AWDHhAHjrK7x2IkYlXdwcc"

The 10-day response period starts with the first calendar day after the date of receipt. (Civ. Code § 10.)  You may be contacted by the department if there are questions regarding your request.

title: All transfer receipt forms from Salem Police Department

communications.communication:
To Whom It May Concern:

Pursuant to the Massachusetts Public Records Law, I hereby request the following records:

From July 1, 2024 to the receipt of this request: all "transfer receipt forms" as described by sections III.B and IV.A of Chapter 156 of the Salem Police department manual titled "Temporarily Secured property for people experiencing homelessness" that have been issued by the Salem Police Department.

I also request that, if appropriate, fees be waived as this request is in the public interest, as suggested but not stipulated by the recommendations of the Massachusetts Supervisor of Public Records. I am a local reporter for the street newspaper Under The Broom and I would ask fees associated with this request, if necessary, be waived as the nature of the records surround low-income and unhoused communities. The requested documents will be made available to the general public free of charge as part of the public information service at MuckRock.com, and is not made for commercial usage.

I expect the request to be filled in an accessible format, including for screen readers, which provide text-to-speech for persons unable to read print. Files that are not accessible to screen readers include, for example, .pdf image files as well as physical documents.

In the event that there are fees, I would be grateful if you would inform me of the total charges in advance of fulfilling my request. I would prefer the request filled electronically, by e-mail attachment if available or CD-ROM if not.

Thank you in advance for your anticipated cooperation in this matter. I look forward to receiving your response to this request within 10 business days, as the statute requires.

Sincerely,

Adam Nuñez

title: ICE: Removal of pro-immigration banner in Washington, DC

communications.subject: Freedom of Information Act Request: ICE: Removal of pro-immigration banner in Washington, DC
communications.communication:
To Whom It May Concern:

Pursuant to the Freedom of Information Act, I hereby request the following records:

1. Any records pertaining to a patrol between August 11-15, 2025, at Lamont St. NW and Mt. Pleasant St. SW, in Washington, D.C., which is depicted in these videos: https://bsky.app/profile/alexkoma.bsky.social/post/3lwhguqpsb22r and https://x.com/icegov/status/1957210426111930828.

2. Any photographs, audio, or video captured by the law enforcement officials or employees during the above-mentioned patrol. This includes all raw and unedited video recorded by the device used to record this video (https://x.com/icegov/status/1957210426111930828) on the date that video (i.e., https://x.com/icegov/status/1957210426111930828) was recorded.

REQUEST FOR EXPEDITED PROCESSING:

I request that this request be expedited under 6 CFR § 5.5(e)(1)(ii) for the following reasons:

1. I certify the following to be true and correct: My organization is primarily engaged in disseminating information. The Foundation for Individual Rights and Expression (FIRE) maintains a news website at https://thefire.org/news, through which its staff members regularly publish news stories and editorial content concerning the activities of governments, government officials, and other persons or organizations of public concern. I am a staff member of FIRE. I frequently write about matters involving the First Amendment and free expression, including on FIRE's website. See, e.g., https://www.thefire.org/news-archive?author=303. A substantial component of my duties as a staff member of FIRE is to obtain information through public records requests, including through the Freedom of Information Act, which I or my colleagues then share through FIRE's website and social media channels. I also publish news and other information of public concern via "X" (https://x.com/adamsteinbaugh) and "Bluesky" (https://bsky.app/profile/adamsteinbaugh.bsky.social).

2. The requested information concerns an actual or alleged government activity, namely the federal government's removal of a banner in a public park during a patrol of Washington, D.C.

3. The requested information extends beyond the public's right to know about government activity generally and instead has a particular value that would be lost if not processed on an expedited basis. The information pertains to a news story of public interest, as exemplified by U.S. Immigration and Customs Enforcement's decision to publicize the video on its official social media account and by news coverage of the event.

Examples of recent articles demonstrating the public's ongoing and current interest in this information include articles:

a. https://www.wusa9.com/article/news/dmv-immigration/mount-pleasant-ice-immigration-federal-takeover-trump-donald-dc-washington/65-b6bfbde6-030d-41e7-8c46-4f0b96944a3a
b. https://www.wusa9.com/article/news/dmv-immigration/ice-immigration-dc-washington-mount-pleasant/65-d3517d58-d9e1-4f47-974b-e8ad4575a4d4

REQUEST FOR A FEE WAIVER OR REDUCED FEES:

I request, under 6 CFR § 5.11(k), a waiver or reduction of fees for the following reasons:

1. Disclosure of the requested information is in the public interest because its disclosure would shed light on the operations or activities of the government. The requested information pertains specifically to controversial conduct by law enforcement officers with the approval of officials at the Department of Homeland Security and/or Immigration and Customs Enforcement.

2. Disclosure of the requested information would be likely to contribute significantly to public understanding of those operations or activities. Disclosure of the requested information would meaningfully inform the public about the Department's activities and operations.

3. Disclosure of the requested information will contribute to the understanding of a reasonably broad audience of persons interested in the subject, as opposed to the individual understanding of the requester. The requestor is a licensed attorney who practices First Amendment law. As such, the requestor will be able to effectively convey information to the public. Further, the requestor is a representative of the news media. The requestor and his employer, the Foundation for Individual Rights and Expression, gather information of potential interest to a segment of the public, turns that information into distinct works (including through its news website, located at https://thefire.org/news), and distributes that information to the public. The information requested here relates to information that is about current events or that would be of current interest to the public. The requestor's past publication record (in addition to FIRE's articles available at https://thefire.org/news) is available at https://www.thefire.org/news-archive?author=303.

4. The requested information is not primarily in the commercial interest of the requester. The requestor works for a nonprofit organization and the records are not sought for a commercial purpose.

The requested documents will be made available to the general public, and this request is not being made for commercial purposes.

In the event that there are fees, I would be grateful if you would inform me of the total charges in advance of fulfilling my request. I would prefer the request filled electronically, by e-mail attachment if available or CD-ROM if not.

Thank you in advance for your anticipated cooperation in this matter. I look forward to receiving your response to this request within 20 business days, as the statute requires.

Sincerely,

Adam Steinbaugh

title: Inventory of Surveillance Technologies, Products, and Services

communications.communication:
To Whom It May Concern:

This request is made pursuant to Oregon’s Public Records Law, ORS 192.311–192.478.

Timeframe:  January 1, 2019 to the present. If a different start date will materially expedite production, please advise.

Scope:
I request records sufficient to identify all surveillance technologies, products, and services acquired, licensed, or subscribed to by Lane County, including the Lane County Sheriff's Office (LCSO), or acquired by other County departments on LCSO’s behalf, whether funded by County funds or grants.

Definitions:
Surveillance technology: Any device, system, software, or service primarily used to monitor, collect, analyze, or share information about individuals, vehicles, or their activities. This includes fixed or mobile systems, cloud services, analytics, and data-sharing platforms.
Examples (non-exhaustive):
- Automated license plate readers (ALPR) and related analytics;
- Fixed CCTV and video management systems; vehicle/in-car and body-worn cameras and any automated analysis modules (e.g., object/face/weapon detection, transcription);
- Drones/UAS and payloads; pole or trailer-mounted cameras; mobile surveillance platforms;
- Facial recognition or other biometric systems (fingerprint/AFIS, iris, voice); image/video analytics; “real-time crime center” platforms;
- Audio/acoustic systems (e.g., gunshot detection) and other sensor networks;
- Social media monitoring/OSINT tools; web scraping; keyword/geo-fencing analytics;
- Cell-site simulators and related tooling; device location tracking services; forensic extraction/analysis tools (e.g., mobile device/computer forensics);
- Data broker and investigative intelligence subscriptions (e.g., commercial person-locator, vehicle, or identity data); information-sharing systems with external agencies; portals that aggregate criminal justice data.
Exclusions (to narrow burden): Routine office IT and productivity tools (e.g., email, word processing, endpoint antivirus) are excluded unless they include surveillance-specific modules or analytics used as described above.

Scope:
1) Technology and software inventories
1.1) Any current or historical inventories, registries, or lists that identify LCSO’s hardware, software, platforms, or cloud services, including:
- Software/subscription inventories or SaaS/license lists;
- Fixed-asset registers for surveillance or public safety equipment;
- Camera registries or maps (fixed, mobile, trailer-mounted, or vendor-hosted);
- “System of record” or application portfolio lists maintained by LCSO or County IT.
1.2) For each entry, please include, where maintained: system name, vendor, product/module, deployment dates, quantity, status (active/inactive), data types collected, internal owner/custodian, and funding source. Preferred format: CSV/Excel.

2) Policies and inventories prepared for oversight that describe surveillance-related systems including:
- Technology inventories
- “Surveillance impact reports” 
- Privacy impact assessments
- Data protection impact assessments (DPIA)
- Data governance catalogs
- CJIS system listings

Custodians and forwarding:
- This request likely involves LCSO, County IT, County Procurement/Purchasing (contracts, POs, and vendor payments), and the District Attorney (agreements and data-sharing). 
- If LCSO does not hold all records, please forward this request to the appropriate custodians and advise.

Search guidance (not limiting): 
- Keywords in descriptions or titles: “surveillance,” “ALPR,” “license plate,” “Flock,” “Vigilant,” “Genetec,” “Milestone,” “BriefCam,” “Veritone,” “ZeroEyes,” “ShotSpotter/SoundThinking,” “drone/UAS,” “facial recognition,” “biometric,” “AFIS,” “cell-site simulator,” “Cellebrite,” “GrayKey,” “OSINT,” “social media monitoring,” “databroker,” “LexisNexis Accurint,” “CLEAR,” “Thomson Reuters,” “Babel Street,” “Dataminr,” “Voyager,” “PredPol/Geolitica,” “Banjo,” “Palantir,” “WatchGuard,” “Axon,” “Genetec Clearance,” “evidence.com,” “real-time crime center,” “situational awareness,” “acoustic,” “gunshot,” “forensic,” “extraction.”
- Systems likely to contain responsive records: contract register, procurement/PO system, accounts payable/vendor payments, IT asset and software inventory systems.

Preferred Format:
- Please provide records electronically via email or secure download. 
- Lists and ledgers in CSV/Excel.
- Contracts and documents in searchable PDF.

Fee Waiver Request:
I request a fee waiver under ORS 192.324(5) because disclosure primarily benefits the public by enabling oversight of surveillance technology use and their public impact. I am requesting these records for noncommercial purposes and will make the results publicly available. These records will be actively shared and used by community groups throughout Lane County. If fees will exceed $50, please provide a written cost estimate and do not proceed without confirmation.

If any portions are withheld or redacted, please produce all segregable nonexempt material and cite the specific statutory basis for each withholding. If no records exist for a category, please say so.

If any part of this request is considered overly broad, please contact me to discuss reasonable narrowing.

Please contact me if you have questions

Sincerely,

Seth May

- Fixed CCTV and video management systems; vehicle/in‑car and body‑worn cameras and any automated analysis modules (e.g., object/face/weapon detection, transcription);
- Drones/UAS and payloads; pole or trailer‑mounted cameras; mobile surveillance platforms;
- Facial recognition or other biometric systems (fingerprint/AFIS, iris, voice); image/video analytics; “real‑time crime center” platforms;
- Audio/acoustic systems (e.g., gunshot detection) and other sensor networks;
- Social media monitoring/OSINT tools; web scraping; keyword/geo‑fencing analytics;
- Cell‑site simulators and related tooling; device location tracking services; forensic extraction/analysis tools (e.g., mobile device/computer forensics);
- Data broker and investigative intelligence subscriptions (e.g., commercial person‑locator, vehicle, or identity data); information‑sharing systems with external agencies; portals that aggregate criminal justice data.
Exclusions (to narrow burden): Routine office IT and productivity tools (e.g., email, word processing, endpoint antivirus) are excluded unless they include surveillance‑specific modules or analytics used as described above.

Scope:
1) Technology and software inventories
1.1) Any current or historical inventories, registries, or lists that identify EPD’s hardware, software, platforms, or cloud services, including:
- Software/subscription inventories or SaaS/license lists;
- Fixed‑asset registers for surveillance or public safety equipment;
- Camera registries or maps (fixed, mobile, trailer‑mounted, or vendor‑hosted);
- “System of record” or application portfolio lists maintained by EPD or City IT.
1.2) For each entry, please include, where maintained: system name, vendor, product/module, deployment dates, quantity, status (active/inactive), data types collected, internal owner/custodian, and funding source. Preferred format: CSV/Excel.

2) Policies and inventories prepared for oversight that describe surveillance-related systems including:
- Technology inventories
- “Surveillance impact reports” 
- Privacy impact assessments
- Data protection impact assessments (DPIA)
- Data governance catalogs
- CJIS system listings

Custodians and forwarding:
- This request likely involves EPD, City IT, City Procurement/Finance (contracts, POs, and vendor payments), and the City Attorney (agreements and data‑sharing). 
- If EPD does not hold all records, please forward this request to the appropriate custodians and advise.

Search guidance (not limiting): 
- Keywords in descriptions or titles: “surveillance,” “ALPR,” “license plate,” “Flock,” “Vigilant,” “Genetec,” “Milestone,” “BriefCam,” “Veritone,” “ZeroEyes,” “ShotSpotter/SoundThinking,” “drone/UAS,” “facial recognition,” “biometric,” “AFIS,” “cell‑site simulator,” “Cellebrite,” “GrayKey,” “OSINT,” “social media monitoring,” “databroker,” “LexisNexis Accurint,” “CLEAR,” “Thomson Reuters,” “Babel Street,” “Dataminr,” “Voyager,” “PredPol/Geolitica,” “Banjo,” “Palantir,” “WatchGuard,” “Axon,” “Genetec Clearance,” “evidence.com,” “real‑time crime center,” “situational awareness,” “acoustic,” “gunshot,” “forensic,” “extraction.”
- Systems likely to contain responsive records: contract register, procurement/PO system, accounts payable/vendor payments, IT asset and software inventory systems.

Preferred Format:
- Please provide records electronically via email or secure download. 
- Lists and ledgers in CSV/Excel.
- Contracts and documents in searchable PDF.

Fee Waiver Request:
I request a fee waiver under ORS 192.324(5) because disclosure primarily benefits the public by informing community understanding of surveillance-based enforcement and public impact. I am requesting these records for noncommercial purposes and intend to make the results publicly available. These records will be actively shared and used by community groups throughout Eugene. If fees will exceed $50, please provide a written cost estimate and do not proceed without confirmation.

If any portions are withheld or redacted, please produce all segregable nonexempt material and cite the specific statutory basis for each withholding. If no records exist for a category, please say so.

If any part of this request is considered overly broad, please contact me to discuss reasonable narrowing.

Please contact me if you have questions

Sincerely,

Seth May

title: Stops Initiated or Influenced by Flock/ALPR Alerts

communications.subject: Oregon Public Records Law Request: Stops Initiated or Influenced by Flock/ALPR Alerts
communications.communication:
To Whom It May Concern:

This request is made pursuant to Oregon’s Public Records Law, ORS 192.311–192.478.

Timeframe: From May 1, 2025 to present.

Scope:
I am seeking records about police stops initiated or materially influenced by automated license plate reader (ALPR) alerts generated by Flock Safety systems.

1. Stop-level records
1.1)  All records that document vehicle or pedestrian stops that were initiated or materially influenced by an ALPR/Flock alert within the timeframe. This includes traffic stops where the plate or vehicle was flagged by a Flock camera.
1.2)  For each stop, please provide, to the extent maintained:
- Incident/case number; CAD event number
- Date and start/end time of stop
- Stop location (block-level or coordinates), patrol district/beat
- Involved unit(s) and officer ID(s)
- Stated legal basis/reason for stop
- Whether the ALPR/Flock hit was the sole basis or a contributing factor
- ALPR hit details: plate read, state, match reason/source (e.g., stolen vehicle, BOLO, warrant, expired registration), hit confidence, associated hotlist or BOLO identifier, camera ID and camera location, Flock event ID if available
- Subject outcome(s): warning/citation(s) with statute codes, search conducted (yes/no; consent/probable cause), arrest(s) with charges, tow/impound, no action
- Any officer narrative or disposition text
- Demographic fields collected for stop data reporting, if maintained (e.g., perceived race/ethnicity, age, gender), recognizing personal identifiers may be redacted
- Use-of-force indicator if tracked at stop level
1.3) If such fields do not exist, please state so.
1.4) Preferred format: CSV or Excel for tabular fields; PDFs for narratives; please include a data dictionary/code sheets for field names and values.

2) CAD/RMS queries and reports
2.1) Any standard or ad hoc CAD/RMS reports that list stops associated with ALPR/Flock hits (e.g., nature/type codes “ALPR,” “FLOCK,” “LPR,” or similar), for the timeframe.
2.2) If a flag/field exists in CAD/RMS linking a stop to an ALPR hit, please export all records with that field populated for the timeframe.
2.3) If such fields do not exist, please state so.

3) Flock Safety logs tied to stops
3.1) Flock “Hit” or “Alert” logs for the timeframe that resulted in officer action or a stop, including: timestamp, camera ID/location, plate read, associated hotlist entry, hit confidence, responding unit/officer (if recorded), acknowledgement/dispatch notes, event ID.
3.2) Any exports or audit logs that show user access or queries directly associated with the above stops.
3.3) Preferred format: CSV/Excel.

4) Metadata and codebooks
4.1) Data dictionaries, schemas, and code sheets for relevant CAD/RMS tables/fields used to record stop reasons, dispositions, ALPR associations, and Flock event identifiers.

5) If records are not tracked:
5.1) If EPD does not track whether a stop was initiated or influenced by an ALPR/Flock hit, please provide:
5.1.1) A written explanation of how such stops could be identified, if at all;
5.1.2) The names of any fields, codes, or report names you considered; and
5.1.3) The specific database systems searched (e.g., CAD, RMS, Flock portal) and the search queries used.

If the above is burdensome, please first produce:
- A stop-level dataset limited to the most recent 30 days; or
- A monthly aggregate count of ALPR/Flock-initiated stops and outcomes for the full timeframe.

Preferred Format: 
- Please provide records electronically via email or secure download. 
- Data tables in CSV/Excel preferred
- Documents in searchable PDF.

Fee Waiver Request
I request a fee waiver under ORS 192.324(5) because disclosure primarily benefits the public by informing community understanding of ALPR-driven enforcement and public impact. I am requesting these records for noncommercial purposes and intend to make the results publicly available. These records will be actively shared and used by community groups throughout Eugene. If fees will exceed $50, please provide a written cost estimate and do not proceed without confirmation.

If you withhold or redact any portion, please produce all segregable nonexempt material and cite the specific statutory basis for each redaction or withholding.

Please contact me if you have questions

Sincerely,

Seth May

title: ALPR / Flock Policies, Training, and Verification Procedures for Enforcement

communications.subject: Oregon Public Records Law Request: ALPR / Flock Policies, Training, and Verification Procedures for Enforcement
communications.communication:
To Whom It May Concern:
This request is made pursuant to Oregon’s Public Records Law, ORS 192.311–192.478.

Timeframe: 1/1/2025 to present

Scope:
I request non‑email records covering policies, SOPs, directives, training materials, and legal guidance on:
- When and how Flock/ALPR alerts may be used to initiate or justify stops or detentions;
- Requirements for independent corroboration or verification before enforcement action;
- Documentation/reporting expectations for ALPR‑related stops;
- Procedures for verifying hits and handling mismatches/false positives;
- Audit, QA, and error‑rate monitoring related to ALPR; and
- Retention, access, and dissemination restrictions.
- Include revision histories or policy memos explaining changes. 

Preferred Format: 
- Please provide records electronically via email or secure download. 
- Searchable PDFs. 

Please forward to the appropriate custodian (e.g., policy/training/legal custodians) as needed. 

Fee Waiver Request
I request a fee waiver under ORS 192.324(5) because disclosure primarily benefits the public by informing community understanding of ALPR-driven enforcement and public impact. I am requesting these records for noncommercial purposes and intend to make the results publicly available. These records will be actively shared and used by community groups throughout Eugene. If fees will exceed $50, please provide a written cost estimate and do not proceed without confirmation.

Please cite specific statutes for any redactions.

Please contact me if you have questions

Sincerely,

Seth May

title: ALPR / Flock Placement Methodologies and Siting Analyses

communications.subject: Oregon Public Records Law Request: ALPR / Flock Placement Methodologies and Siting Analyses
communications.communication:
To Whom It May Concern:

This request is made pursuant to Oregon’s Public Records Law, ORS 192.311–192.478.

Timeframe: The earliest planning for Flock/ALPR to present

Scope:
I request non‑email records that detail how ALPR/Flock camera locations were selected, including criteria, methodologies, scoring rubrics, maps/heat maps, datasets used (crime, CFS, traffic), equity/privacy impact analyses, siting plans (“camera placement plans”), and any MOUs/permissions related to placement on public or private property. Include revisions/updates over time and any vendor‑provided siting analyses. 
Possible Custodians Involved:
- EPD Operations/Patrol leadership (Captains/Lieutenants) and Traffic Unit supervisors — decision memos and deployment plans.
- Crime Analysis/Analytics Unit — hotspot analyses, criteria, heat maps, scoring rubrics, underlying datasets.
- EPD Technology/Systems Unit and City IT — Flock portal access, camera inventory, network/power notes, exports.
- EPD Training/Policy or Professional Standards — any SOPs/guidance on siting considerations.
- City GIS — ArcGIS layers, siting maps, geodata used for analysis.
- Public Works/Transportation/Right‑of‑Way — pole/trailer placement, ROW permits, traffic control plans, utility locates.
- City Procurement/Finance — vendor proposals, statements of work, and siting deliverables.
- City Attorney/Risk — MOUs/property permissions, indemnity or privacy impact language tied to locations.
- External utilities and partners (if applicable) — e.g., Eugene Water & Electric Board (pole attachment/energizing), school districts, HOAs, or businesses that host cameras.

Forward to the appropriate custodians as needed.

Systems/locations to search:
- Flock Safety portal (and admin exports):
--- Camera Locations/Inventory export (CSV), including camera IDs, lat/long, status.
--- Activity by Camera/Detections reports used to justify or reevaluate sites.
--- Any “Siting” or “Deployment” PDFs provided by Flock (often uploaded/linked via the account).
- ArcGIS/City GIS:
--- MXD/APRX projects, hosted feature layers, shapefiles, GeoJSON/KML for proposed/approved camera locations and analysis layers (crime, CFS, traffic volumes, crashes).
- CAD/RMS attachments or SharePoint/Teams/Network drives: “ALPR,” “Flock,” “Siting,” “Deployment,” “Camera Placement” folders.
- Permit/asset systems:
--- ROW/encroachment permit databases, pole attachment records, utility locate tickets, work orders.
- Procurement/contract registers: SOWs, vendor responses with siting sections.

Document types/titles that are commonly used
- “Camera Placement Plan,” “Siting Analysis,” “Site Selection Criteria,” “Hotspot/Heat Map,” “Ingress/Egress Analysis,” “Coverage/ROI Assessment,” “Deployment Plan,” “Pilot Report,” “Location Proposal,” “Siting Walk Notes,” “Camera Map,” “Camera Inventory,” “Re‑siting/Relocation Justification.”
- Vendor‑authored: “Flock Siting Recommendations,” “Deployment Overview,” “Success Plan,” “Falcon install plan,” “Trailer deployment plan,” “Camera location workbook.”

Keywords and vendor terms (use singular/plural and acronyms)
- Core: Flock, “Flock Safety,” ALPR, LPR, “license plate,” “camera placement,” siting, “site selection,” “deployment plan,” “location proposal,” “mount,” “install,” “pole,” “trailer,” “solar,” “power,” “LTE,” “ingress,” “egress,” hotspot, “heat map,” scoring, rubric, criteria.
- Validation/constraints: ROW, right‑of‑way, encroachment, utility locate, easement, MOU, permission, indemnity, privacy, equity, impact, “traffic control plan.”
- Camera/asset fields: “camera ID,” “Falcon,” “Raven,” “camera list,” “camera map,” “lat,” “lon,” “coordinates.”
- Comparative vendors (captures “why here/why this” docs if alternatives were considered): Rekor, Vigilant/Motorola, Genetec AutoVu, OpenALPR

Preferred Format: 
- Please provide records electronically via email or secure download. 
- GIS layers and files (shp, gdb, aprx/mxd, kml/kmz, GeoJSON) for proposed and final camera locations, plus any heat maps or kernel density rasters used for siting.
- Tabular datasets used in siting: crime incidents (especially UUV/UUMV/stolen vehicle recovery), calls for service, traffic volumes, collision data — with data dictionaries.
- Camera inventory in CSV with fields: camera id, name, type, status (proposed/active/inactive), install date, location (address, lat/long), host/owner (public/private), and justification/rationale if tracked.
- Searchable PDFs for other documents

Fee Waiver Request:
I request a fee waiver under ORS 192.324(5) because disclosure primarily benefits the public by informing community understanding of ALPR-driven enforcement and public impact. I am requesting these records for noncommercial purposes and the results will be made publicly available. These records will be actively shared and used by community groups throughout Eugene. If fees will exceed $50, please provide a written cost estimate and do not proceed without confirmation.
Please cite specific statutes for any redactions.

Please contact me if you have questions

Sincerely,

Seth May

title: ALPR / Flock Procurement Rationale

communications.subject: Oregon Public Records Law Request: ALPR / Flock Procurement Rationale
communications.communication:
To Whom It May Concern:

This request is made pursuant to Oregon’s Public Records Law, ORS 192.311–192.478.

Time frame: The earliest planning for Flock/ALPR to present

Scope:
I request non‑email records from the earliest planning for Flock/ALPR through the present that describe or authorize the acquisition of Flock Safety ALPR equipment/services, including: 
1. Needs/problem statements
2. Cost‑benefit or impact assessments
3. Budget justifications
4. Staff reports and meeting minutes
5. Procurement justifications (RFP/sole source)
6. Vendor proposals
7. Statements of work
8. Evaluations tied to expected or actual outcomes. 

If any responsive records are held by City Procurement/Finance or other departments, please forward.

Preferred Format: 
- Please provide records electronically via email or secure download. 
- Tabular data as CSV/Excel 
- Documents as searchable PDFs 

Fee Waiver Request:
I request a fee waiver under ORS 192.324(5) because disclosure primarily benefits the public by informing community understanding of ALPR-driven enforcement, public impact and awareness of budget based items. I am requesting these records for noncommercial purposes and the results will be made publicly available. These records will be actively shared and used by community groups throughout Eugene. If fees will exceed $50, please provide a written cost estimate and do not proceed without confirmation.

Please cite specific statutes for any redactions.

Please contact me if you have questions

Sincerely,

Seth May

title: Mark Poloncarz, Kevin Riford, Christina Little Riford Package - Erie County Rath Building

communications.subject: Freedom of Information Act Request: Mark Poloncarz, Kevin Riford, Christina Little Riford Package - Erie County Rath Building
communications.communication:
To Whom It May Concern:

Pursuant to the Freedom of Information Act, I hereby request the following records:

1.) Any and all records regarding the below April 2019 article published by WGRZ Ch. 2 News Buffalo regarding the 'suspicious' package dropped off at the Rath Building. 


https://www.wgrz.com/article/news/brother-and-sister-believe-package-that-caused-concern-for-poloncarz-came-from-them/71-df54a2b2-c826-4ca1-8634-64fdd6bd1c2d

In early April 2019, a brother and sister came forward believing that a suspicious package delivered to Erie County Executive Mark Poloncarz’s office in mid-March may have originated from them. The package, addressed personally and marked “urgent” without a return address, triggered alarm at the office and ultimately led Poloncarz to adopt an armed security detail. The sibling duo—Christina Little and Kevin Riford—say the envelope contained extensive documentation concerning a contentious custody dispute and allegations of judicial corruption in Niagara County. They hoped Poloncarz would either take action or forward their concerns to Governor Cuomo. After passing routine security screening, the package was delivered to a receptionist on the 16th floor of the Rath Building, along with similar documents sent to local media outlets.  Shortly afterward, a sheriff’s investigator visited Christina’s home seeking Kevin. The siblings were confused by the level of concern raised over what appeared to them to be harmless legal documents. Poloncarz later confirmed the package played a part in increasing security measures, though he did not personally read the contents—his staff reviewed it after authorities cleared it as non-dangerous

The requested documents will be made available to the general public, and this request is not being made for commercial purposes.

In the event that there are fees, I would be grateful if you would inform me of the total charges in advance of fulfilling my request. I would prefer the request filled electronically, by e-mail attachment if available or CD-ROM if not.

Thank you in advance for your anticipated cooperation in this matter. I look forward to receiving your response to this request within 20 business days, as the statute requires.

Sincerely,

The Riford Family

title: Kevin Riford Reports Niagara County Bail Bond Fraud to NYS Department of Financial Services - E-mail Communications & More (Attempt #2)

communications.communication:
To Whom It May Concern:

Pursuant to the New York Freedom of Information Law, I hereby request the following records:

On 01/08/2025 I submitted a request for the records below. My request was denied citing "The records requested are records of a current Department investigation, and thus are exempt from disclosure pursuant to N.Y. Public Officers Law § 87(2)(e)(i), which excepts from disclosure records that are compiled for law enforcement purposes and that, if disclosed, would interfere with law enforcement investigations" as the reason for denial. SEE EXHIBIT A

The investigation is now closed (see attached exhibit b page 18), as such I am resubmitting my original request for email communications in addition to other requests for documents. Please provide the following:

1.)  Any and all emails and attachments received by william.fedrau@dfs.ny.gov, laura.sankey@dfs.ny.gov, warren.lester@dfs.ny.gov from kevinriford1@protonmail.com for the following time period 01/01/2023 through 01/23/2025

2.) Any and all emails and attachments sent from william.fedrau@dfs.ny.gov, laura.sankey@dfs.ny.gov, warren.lester@dfs.ny.gov to kevinriford1@protonmail to for the following time period 01/01/2023 through 01/23/2025. I have attached copies of the referenced email communications for clarity. SEE EXHIBIT B

3.) A copy of the email and letter attached as EXHIBIT C - which was sent to Niagara County DA Brian Seaman, Erie County DA Michael Keane and others.

4.) All investigative records for Dept. of Financial services case #, CSB-2023-01537055, including the below: 

Complaint intake forms, notes, or logs relating to CSB-2023-01537055 submissions.

Case file summary or investigative reports prepared by DFS staff related to CSB-2023-01537055

Interview notes, transcripts, or recordings related to CSB-2023-01537055

Copies of subpoenas issued and responses received related to CSB-2023-01537055

Copies of correspondence sent or received in connection with the investigation (letters, memos, emails not already covered) related to CSB-2023-01537055

Exhibits, attachments, and supporting documents collected during the investigation related to CSB-2023-01537055

Internal memoranda, briefing notes, or recommendations concerning the matter related to CSB-2023-01537055

Final investigative findings, closure memo, or disposition documents related to CSB-2023-01537055

Administrative Records related to CSB-2023-01537055

Logs of record requests, case tracking notes, or audit trail entries related to CSB-2023-01537055

Any inter-agency referrals or communications with the Niagara County DA, Erie County DA, or other law enforcement agencies related to CSB-2023-01537055

Any determination letters or reports sent to complainants or other stakeholders related to CSB-2023-01537055

Pursuant to N.Y. Public Officers Law §§ 87(1)(b)(iii) and 89(3), I request that all records produced in response to this request be provided as certified copies, attesting that they are true and accurate copies of records maintained by the Department of Financial Services.

The requested documents will be made available to the general public, and this request is not being made for commercial purposes.

In the event that there are fees, I would be grateful if you would inform me of the total charges in advance of fulfilling my request. I would prefer the request filled electronically, by e-mail attachment if available or CD-ROM if not.

Thank you in advance for your anticipated cooperation in this matter. I look forward to receiving your response to this request within 5 business days, as the statute requires.

Sincerely,

The Riford Family

title: Johann "Jack" Unterweger FBI File

communications.subject: Freedom of Information Act Request: Johann "Jack" Unterweger FBI File
communications.communication:
To Whom It May Concern:

Pursuant to the Freedom of Information Act, I hereby request the following records:

FBI files pertaining to Johann "Jack" Unterweger (16 August 1950  – 29 June 1994), who was an Austrian serial killer who committed at least twelve murders in Austria, West Germany, Czechoslovakia and the United States. Unterweger was under FBI surveillance circa 1992, when he fled Austria to Miami, where he was arrested on Feb 27, 1992.

https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Jack_Unterweger

Please search first for any prior releases and/or pre-processed files, and release them on a rolling basis before processing any new material generated by this request. 

If no prior releases are available, please kindly conduct a search of the Central Records System, including but not limited to the Electronic Surveillance (ELSUR) Indices, the Microphone Surveillance (MISUR) Indices, the Physical Surveillance (FISUR) Indices, and the Technical Surveillance (TESUR) Indices, however as noted below, please inform me prior to performing any searches incurring fees.

The requested documents will be made available to the general public, and this request is not being made for commercial purposes.

In the event that there are fees, I would be grateful if you would inform me of the total charges in advance of fulfilling my request. I would prefer the request filled electronically, by e-mail attachment if available or CD-ROM if not.

Thank you in advance for your anticipated cooperation in this matter. I look forward to receiving your response to this request within 20 business days, as the statute requires.

Sincerely,

Elizabeth J Klein
