communications.subject: RE: Freedom of Information Act Request: Removal of pro-immigration banner in Washington, DC
communications.communication:
Hello --

This is an amendment to my request and a request for expedited processing.

First, please amend the request to seek:

1. Any records pertaining to a patrol between August 11-15, 2025, at Lamont St. NW and Mt. Pleasant St. SW, in Washington, D.C., which is depicted in these videos: https://bsky.app/profile/alexkoma.bsky.social/post/3lwhguqpsb22r and https://x.com/icegov/status/1957210426111930828.

2. Any photographs, audio, or video captured by the law enforcement officials or employees during the above-mentioned patrol. This includes all raw and unedited video recorded by the device used to record this video (https://x.com/icegov/status/1957210426111930828) on the date that video (i.e., https://x.com/icegov/status/1957210426111930828) was recorded.

REQUEST FOR EXPEDITED PROCESSING:

I request that this request be expedited under 6 CFR § 5.5(e)(1)(ii) for the following reasons:

1. I certify the following to be true and correct: My organization is primarily engaged in disseminating information. The Foundation for Individual Rights and Expression (FIRE) maintains a news website at https://thefire.org/news, through which its staff members regularly publish news stories and editorial content concerning the activities of governments, government officials, and other persons or organizations of public concern. I am a staff member of FIRE. I frequently write about matters involving the First Amendment and free expression, including on FIRE's website. See, e.g., https://www.thefire.org/news-archive?author=303. A substantial component of my duties as a staff member of FIRE is to obtain information through public records requests, including through the Freedom of Information Act, which I or my colleagues then share through FIRE's website and social media channels. I also publish news and other information of public concern via "X" (https://x.com/adamsteinbaugh) and "Bluesky" (https://bsky.app/profile/adamsteinbaugh.bsky.social).

2. The requested information concerns an actual or alleged government activity, namely the federal government's removal of a banner in a public park during a patrol of Washington, D.C.

3. The requested information extends beyond the public's right to know about government activity generally and instead has a particular value that would be lost if not processed on an expedited basis. The information pertains to a news story of public interest, as exemplified by U.S. Immigration and Customs Enforcement's decision to publicize the video on its official social media account and by news coverage of the event.

Examples of recent articles demonstrating the public's ongoing and current interest in this information include articles:

a. https://www.wusa9.com/article/news/dmv-immigration/mount-pleasant-ice-immigration-federal-takeover-trump-donald-dc-washington/65-b6bfbde6-030d-41e7-8c46-4f0b96944a3a
b. https://www.wusa9.com/article/news/dmv-immigration/ice-immigration-dc-washington-mount-pleasant/65-d3517d58-d9e1-4f47-974b-e8ad4575a4d4

REQUEST FOR A FEE WAIVER OR REDUCED FEES:

I request, under 6 CFR § 5.11(k), a waiver or reduction of fees for the following reasons:

1. Disclosure of the requested information is in the public interest because its disclosure would shed light on the operations or activities of the government. The requested information pertains specifically to controversial conduct by law enforcement officers with the approval of officials at the Department of Homeland Security and/or Immigration and Customs Enforcement.

2. Disclosure of the requested information would be likely to contribute significantly to public understanding of those operations or activities. Disclosure of the requested information would meaningfully inform the public about the Department's activities and operations.

3. Disclosure of the requested information will contribute to the understanding of a reasonably broad audience of persons interested in the subject, as opposed to the individual understanding of the requester. The requestor is a licensed attorney who practices First Amendment law. As such, the requestor will be able to effectively convey information to the public. Further, the requestor is a representative of the news media. The requestor and his employer, the Foundation for Individual Rights and Expression, gather information of potential interest to a segment of the public, turns that information into distinct works (including through its news website, located at https://thefire.org/news), and distributes that information to the public. The information requested here relates to information that is about current events or that would be of current interest to the public. The requestor's past publication record (in addition to FIRE's articles available at https://thefire.org/news) is available at https://www.thefire.org/news-archive?author=303.

4. The requested information is not primarily in the commercial interest of the requester. The requestor works for a nonprofit organization and the records are not sought for a commercial purpose.

communications.subject: Department of Homeland Security FOIA 2025-HQFO-05902 Acknowledgment
communications.communication:
08/18/2025 

SENT VIA E-MAIL TO:  191494-18990586@requests.muckrock.com 

Adam  Steinbaugh 
MuckRock News DEPT MR 191494 
Boston, Massachusetts 02115 

Re:  2025-HQFO-05902 

Dear Requester: 

This acknowledges receipt of your Freedom of Information Act (FOIA) request to the Department of Homeland Security (DHS), dated 8/15/2025, and seeking records regarding federal offices at Lamont St. NW and Mt. Pleasant St. SW. 

Your request was received in this office on 8/15/2025. 

After careful review of your FOIA request, we determined that your request is too broad in scope or did not specifically identify the records which you are seeking. 

Based on the video link you provided, we are unable to determine what DHS component officers were at that location. Please provide more information. 

Records must be described in reasonably sufficient detail to enable government employees who are familiar with the subject area to locate records without placing an unreasonable burden upon the agency.  For this reason, 6 C.F.R. Part 5 §5.3(b) of the DHS FOIA regulations require that you describe the records you are seeking with as much information as possible to ensure that our search can locate them with a reasonable amount of effort.  Whenever possible, a request should include specific information about each record sought, such as the date, title or name, author, recipients, and subject matter of the records, if known, or the DHS component or office you believe created and/or controls the record. The FOIA does not require an agency to create new records, answer questions posed by requesters, or attempt to interpret a request that does not identify specific records. 

A list of DHS Component and Offices is located online to aid in providing more information: https://www.dhs.gov/operational-and-support-components.  Additionally, your identified DHS Components or Offices may have their own FOIA office for FOIA request submissions.  A list of DHS FOIA Offices is located online:  https://www.dhs.gov/foia-contact-information.  If your identified DHS Component or Office has a FOIA office, please submit directly to that office.  Otherwise, respond back with your additional information. 

Please resubmit your request containing a reasonable description of the records you are seeking.  This is not a denial of your request.  Upon receipt of a perfected request, you will be advised as to the status of your request.  If we do not hear from you within 30 days from the date of this letter, we will assume you are no longer interested in this FOIA request, and the case will be administratively closed. 

You have a right to appeal the above determination.  Should you wish to do so, you must send your appeal and a copy of this letter, within 90 days of the date of this letter, to:  Privacy Office, Attn: FOIA Appeals, U.S. Department of Homeland Security, 2707 Martin Luther King Jr. Avenue, SE, Mail Stop 0655, Washington, D.C. 20528-0655, following the procedures outlined in the DHS FOIA regulations at 6 C.F.R. Part 5 § 5.5(e)(2).  Your envelope and letter should be marked “FOIA Appeal.”  Copies of the FOIA and DHS FOIA regulations are available at www.dhs.gov/foia. 
You may contact the DHS FOIA Public Liaison at 202-343-1743 for any further assistance and to discuss any aspect of your request.  You may also contact OGIS at the National Archives and Records Administration to inquire about the FOIA mediation services they offer.  The contact information for OGIS is as follows: Office of Government Information Services, National Archives and Records Administration, 8601 Adelphi Road-OGIS, College Park, Maryland 20740-6001, e-mail at ogis@nara.gov; telephone at 202-741-5770; toll free at 1-877-684-6448; or facsimile at 202-741-5769. 

Your request has been assigned reference number 2025-HQFO-05902.  Please refer to this identifier in any future correspondence. If you have any questions, or would like to discuss this matter, please feel free to contact this office at 1-866-431-0486 or at 202-343-1743. 

Regards, 

DHS FOIA, Privacy Office 
Department of Homeland Security 
2707 Martin Luther King Jr. AVE SE 
Mail Stop 0655 
Washington, DC 20528-0655 
E-mail: foia@hq.dhs.gov 
Visit our FOIA website https://www.dhs.gov/foia

communications.communication:
To Whom It May Concern:

Pursuant to the Freedom of Information Act, I hereby request the following records:

An aggregate count of specific visas (O-1A aliens of extraordinary ability, E11 aliens of extraordinary ability, E21 aliens of exceptional ability and national interest waivers) granted to foreign athletes over the last 25 years who identified as transgender women and are no longer eligible for said visas under the USCIS' updated policy (found here: https://www.uscis.gov/newsroom/news-releases/uscis-updating-policy-to-protect-womens-sports). 

I also request communications (emails, text messages, meeting notes, memos) to and from members of USCIS about this policy update. 

I additionally request that, if appropriate, fees be waived as I believe this request is in the public interest. communications.subject: Public Records Request :: R013995-081525
communications.communication:
Dear Patrik Szigeti: 
Thank you for your interest in public records of District of Columbia. Your request has been received and is being processed. Your request was received in this office on 8/15/2025 and given the reference number R013995-081525 for tracking purposes. 
In all future correspondence regarding this request, please reference request number R013995-081525. You can monitor the progress of your request in the " My Records Center". 
 
The District of Columbia is required to respond to your FOIA request within fifteen (15) business days of its receipt.  See D.C. Official Code § 2-532(c)(2011).  However, under certain circumstances, D.C. Official Code § 2-532(d)(2011) authorizes the District to extend, by ten (10) additional days, the deadline by which it must respond to a FOIA request.  One of the circumstances provided by that statute is a case in which the District needs additional time to search for, collect and examine voluminous amounts of records and/or consult with an additional D.C. agency. 
For any questions regarding your request, please contact the FOIA office directly. Find the list of agency Open Government and FOIA contact information by visiting FOIA Contact Information. For ease of reference, we ask that you have your FOIA Reference Number available when you contact the FOIA office. 
Regards, 
District of Columbia

title: Pretrial Detention Policies and Procedures

communications.subject: Indiana Access to Public Records Act Request: Pretrial Detention Policies and Procedures
communications.communication:
To Whom It May Concern:

Pursuant to the Indiana Access to Public Records Act, I hereby request the following records:

1. Policies, Procedures, and Directives: All current written policies, procedures, directives, guidelines, or post orders regarding:
Pretrial detention of arrestees, including timing requirements for probable cause determinations
Bond setting eligibility, conditions, or procedures that differ for out-of-state versus in-state arrestees
Use of commercial surety bond companies
Release procedures and authorization protocols
Any policies governing the 48-hour constitutional detention limit
2: Training & Instruction – Any training materials, handouts, slide decks, manuals, or written instructions provided to jail staff regarding:
Constitutional detention limits and probable cause requirements
Bond procedures for non-resident arrestees
3: Communications – Any memoranda, directives, or internal communications (including emails or bulletins) regarding bond procedures for non-resident arrestees.
4: Contracts & Agreements – Any contracts, agreements, or fee arrangements currently in effect with commercial bonding companies.
5: Audit & Compliance Records – Any internal audit reports, inspection results, or compliance reviews regarding detention policies conducted within the past ten (10) years. 

These items are requested only to the extent they exist and are maintained in the normal course of business.

The requested documents will be made available to the general public, and this request is not being made for commercial purposes.

In the event that there are fees, I would be grateful if you would inform me of the total charges in advance of fulfilling my request. I would prefer the request filled electronically, by e-mail attachment if available or CD-ROM if not.

Thank you in advance for your anticipated cooperation in this matter. I look forward to receiving your response to this request within 7 business days, as the statute requires.

Sincerely,

Whitley Accountabity Project

title: PC Determiniations 2023-2024

communications.subject: Indiana Access to Public Records Act Request: PC Determiniations 2023-2024
communications.communication:
To Whom It May Concern:

Pursuant to the Indiana Access to Public Records Act, I hereby request the following records:

All records relating to probable cause determinations for warrantless arrests processed through Whitley County courts from January 1, 2023 through December 31, 2024:

1. Data Export: An electronic export (spreadsheet or CSV format) of all entries relating to probable cause determinations for warrantless arrests, containing the following fields (if maintained):
Case number / cause number
Defendant's full name
Defendant's city and state of residence (or last known address, with street number redacted if needed)
Date and time of arrest
Warrant-based or warrantless arrest indicator
Date and time of probable cause determination signed
Name and title of judicial officer who signed the probable cause determination
Scheduled date and time of initial hearing/appearance
Actual date and time initial hearing was conducted (if different from scheduled)
Bond type (surety, cash, recognizance, etc.)
Bond amount
Any notation or code indicating residency status (in-state vs. out-of-state)

2. Policy & Procedure Records: Any active or historical administrative orders, local court rules, or written policies governing:
Constitutional timeframes for probable cause determinations (including the 48-hour requirement)
Scheduling procedures and protocols for probable cause hearings
Weekend, holiday, and after-hours procedures for judicial determinations
Bail/bond conditions for out-of-state defendants
The use of commercial surety bonds vs. cash or recognizance bonds

3. Scheduling Records: Any logs, calendars, or records showing:
How probable cause hearings are scheduled and by whom
Standard scheduling practices for warrantless arrests
Any backlogs or delays in scheduling PC determinations
Judicial officer availability for probable cause determinations

4. Metadata or Data Dictionary: If the requested data fields are maintained under different names in your system, please provide a list of the field names and their definitions. If any requested field is not maintained, please identify which fields are unavailable.

These items are requested only to the extent they are recorded in the normal course of business.

The requested documents will be made available to the general public, and this request is not being made for commercial purposes.

In the event that there are fees, I would be grateful if you would inform me of the total charges in advance of fulfilling my request. I would prefer the request filled electronically, by e-mail attachment if available or CD-ROM if not.

Thank you in advance for your anticipated cooperation in this matter. I look forward to receiving your response to this request within 7 business days, as the statute requires.

Sincerely,

Whitley Accountabity Project

title: Chemical and Biological Weapon Incidents within the United States

communications.subject: Freedom of Information Act Request: Chemical and Biological Weapon Incidents within the United States
communications.communication:
To Whom It May Concern:

Pursuant to the Freedom of Information Act, I hereby request the following records:

I am requesting all documents related to military personnel carrying out missions, responses, or other incidents involving chemical or biological weapons, substances, munitions, or agents within the United States of America, including all states and territories,  between January 1, 2005 and August 14, 2025. This includes incident requests from EODIMS on incidents involving such weapons or agents. 

I request that I be properly classified as a news media requester. I am an investigative researcher for Bellingcat, and I am requesting this information in that capacity and request that fees be waived for this request.

I am requesting expedited processing as I am a ”person primarily engaged in disseminating information” and there is urgency to inform the public about the activities of US military personnel, especially as it pertains to incidents involving chemical and biological agents that occur within the United States. 

Bellingcat is widely recognized for its reporting, and publishing regular features on issues of public interest and importance using open source material. 

If you have any questions about my media status, please contact me.

The requested documents will be made available to the general public, and this request is not being made for commercial purposes.

In the event that there are fees, I would be grateful if you would inform me of the total charges in advance of fulfilling my request. I would prefer the request filled electronically, by e-mail attachment if available or CD-ROM if not.

Thank you in advance for your anticipated cooperation in this matter. I look forward to receiving your response to this request within 20 business days, as the statute requires.

Sincerely,

Trevor Ball
